div1.p: Hanson includes the names of medical personnel and the places he has inspected. He mentions the lack of cooperation from locals. He is considering a return to the U.S.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, September 8, 1921
div1.opener:
DIRECCION DE LA CAMPAÑA SANITARIA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
EN LOS
DEPARTAMENTOS DEL NORTE
____
OFICINA CENTRAL
____
Havana
Chiclayo, Peru.
September 8, 1921.
Dr. H.R. Carter,
Washington, D.C.
My Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I have several letters from you which I will endeavor to
answer as best I can. It is always a pleasure and a help to hear from you, You
appreciate and understand this situation better than any other man, and will be
able to judge best of what we are doing and of what we have done.

Your letter of June 29th was forwarded to me in Panama, where I was
for about eleven days, and it seemed a mighty short time at that. I noticed the
hot weather considerably there, and did not get about as much as I had intended
for that reason.

In regard to Seeley I finally decided that I better pay him $400.00
as he wished. Frankly a man earns it in a campaign of this kind, and he has
spared no effort to earn his. He has scarcely had a Sunday since he has been on the
job, and has done a lot of work at night. I sent up a quarterly report which he pre-
pared for me of the first three months after his arrival. If you have not already
seen this you better ask Dr. Rose to let you have it too look it over. It has a great
deal of information which I can not give you in a latter.

I fully appreciate your spirit in wishing to be down here on the job, but
I have been glad for your sake that you have not been here. This campaign has been
so much severer than any of the others that I am quite certain that you would have
had trouble. You know you do not take care of yourself when you are out on a thing of
this kind, and with the hardships we have had I feel quite certain that it would
have done you up for good. I have never before worked like this, and what is more
I wont do it again!! I wanted to show these people that we could get rid of the
fever in spite of their dmanable opposition, and we have succeeded. Contrary to
last year we have protected ourselves on all sides, and are still continuing to do
so. On my way down from Panama I had an opportunity to find out what kind of a
place Port of Pizarro and Tumbes were like, which is a great adavantage to me in
2. H.R.C., September 8, 1921.
planning for the future.

Dr. Caballero had asked for permission to go to Catacaos (to see his
sweetheart I think) so I requested him to look all the important points in the
Department of Piura over before he goes back south. This he is doing at the present
time. I expect him back in the south sometime next week. In regard to the south
you will get a fairly good idea from the copies of the letters (reports of Corrigan)
which I enclosed with other copies which I have sent you in the last few days.

I am glad to note what you say of White's work in New Orleans, he im-
pressed me as a very capable and aggressive man. It seems that Wyman rather
queered Whites report on the N.O. epidemic - did he not?

White stayed a while in Guayaquil and then was on his way to Lima, and
would have arrived about the time of the fiestas or just before, which would have been
time all wasted, so I went aboard and advised him to come ashore at Salaverry to see
what we were doing before he went to Lima. I went with him to Lima, but had very
little time with him in Lima. They were still having their despedidos for the foreign
embassies, so I would not have been able to do any real business, and took my boat
for Panama. I have not heard from Dr. White since. He went up by way of Guayaquil
-how soon he will get to the states I do not know.

You speak of Peru puttin up Lp2050, “each month” - if she had we would not
have needed to ask the I.H.B. for very much. Peru has scarcely put up more than
that sum all told up to date. We will need from the I.H.B. about $10,000, per month
as available working capital in order to be able to make sure of this thing once
and for all. I do not intend to spend that unless it is quite necessary, but I do
not want to be handicapped for what is really needed to insure what it seems that we
now have. I cabled them somewhat to this effect the other day but so far have not
received any answer, they may think that this is a good deal, but they better do it to
insure what they have already spent. The Government is not even paying my salary.
This makes me tired because if they were not paying “Willie” such a fancy salary
they might be able to pay me. Ten thousand will cover everything, and leave a balance,
even the salaries of the American Inspectors.

I am palnning to go to Lima as soon as I can get things properly lined
3. H.R.C., September 8, 1921.
up in the northerns sections, Lambayeque and Libertad. Dr. Canseco is working pretty
well now and takes charge of the office here during my absence, and Tapia in Trujillo.
I have made Mendoza the General Supervisor for the entire Department of Libertad
and have put Cavassa in charge of the Province of Pacasmayo, Dr. Caballero has all
the coast from Libertad to Lima and Callao, so I think we have the entire coast pretty
well taken care of, and all reports are encouraging. My ideas on the Lima proposition
you will get from the copies of the other letters which I have sent up.

It is possible that the epidemic might reach Lima, but I dont think it
will on account of the condition in which we have all this northern section, and what
we have done in the Department of Ancash. This is putting a mighty wide barrier be-
tween Lima and the infected zones, and what is more we are watching everything our-
selves, and taking nobody's word for anything. If anything should happen it would have
to attract the attention of the men we have in these parts, and we would know about
it before it could get a start.

Machado picked up again under a little supervision and was doing very well
when I was in Trujillo last. Quiros resigned when he thought that he was not going to
be the whole cheese in the campaign, and I think that I have been just as well off
without him. He is largely responsible for the spread of the fever to the Depart-
ment of Libertad, on account of his obstinacy when we were here together. Sains is
doing fine, so is Reyes, and I have several others now who are quite good.

I dont know what to say about Wrightson, or what he is doing. He was about
as pigheaded about our recommendations of the quarantine as Cardenas was, and he got
a real mess stirred up at the quarantine station as a consequence. I think he is too
much impressed with his own importance to be able to see things staright.

In so far as my continuing with the stegomya control here is concerned I
presume that I would be better qualified for this job than anyone else except your-
self. I have been thinking about this - of finishing this job but am not ready to
give a final answer now. Conditions have changed much and it is hard to say before-
hand what one ought to do. If I could get a decent place for the family to live I
would bring them to Trujillo, which would be quite a central location for the balance
4. H.R.C., September 8, 1921.
of the campaign. I will investigate this on my next trip down there. The difficulty
about this is Karl. I do not want to bring him back. If I could place him in some
good school in the states where I could be sure that he would be well taken care of
I would send him up and bring the rest of them back down here. What do you think of
that? In that case I would not be away from them more than half of the time.

Sorry you had such an uncomfortable summer. Our weather here has been quite
ideal. Never too hot and never too cold. This is a much better climate than Piura.

To return to the subject of the continuation of the stegomya work, I
note what you say in the copy of your letter to Rose, about the difficulty of con-
tinuing the stegomya work for a year in Peru. It will be difficult to continue this
and I have wondered whether it will be practicable to attempt to continue it for a
year after the last case. I at first figured on continuing it to the end of the
year and later of a possibility of continuing to April. I think that one can be
sufficiently certain by that time. If we have no more cases before that time and
our stegomya index continues as it is, where is the new case coming from? This is
different from last year in that we have spread to out a very great deal and now
have things in such shape that there can be no epidemic in any of the Departments to
the north. If there is special watching to do it seems to me that it should be done
in Lima more than in the north, and in that case would it not be best for me to
transfer my headquarters to Lima, leaving the local offices in charge of these men
who are now looking after them? We are now starting work in Huacho which is a town
of about 10,000, and as Corrigan says has about 50% of containers breeding. With our
present system of fish control we can reduce the index very much faster than before.

Our last know case in Libertad was on the 11th of July, and I think that
is going to remain the last, but we take no chances.
With all good wishes for you and yours,
